For years, the upper tier of American podcasting seemed immovable. News briefings, daily analysis and long-established storytelling shows dominated the charts, setting the tone for what millions listened to on their commutes, workouts and late-night wind-downs. But Apple ’s newly released 2025 rankings tell a different story. A familiar format has been pushed down, a new style has risen to the top and the country’s listening habits are shifting in ways that feel bigger than a simple list.Apple’s new list reveals a dramatic reshuffling, with familiar giants sliding down the chart and unexpected contenders rising to the top. What makes the change so striking is not only who climbed but what the shift says about how Americans are choosing to listen in 2025.At the centre of that shake-up is a new chart-topper: The Joe Rogan Experience. It has moved up from No. 3 last year to become America’s most popular podcast on Apple’s 2025 list. Its ascent pushed long-time leader The Daily from The New York Times into second place, bringing an end to its years-long run at the top.Apple’s rankings confirm what industry watchers have sensed for months. Rogan’s multi-hour, freewheeling political, cultural and scientific conversations have been pulling massive audiences across platforms, and the momentum carried the show to No.1. It also currently ranks first on YouTube’s weekly podcast chart, showcasing its reach beyond traditional audio platforms.Apple’s top 10 for 2025 paints a broader picture of upheaval:Apple’s separate episode ranking also offered surprises:The episode list spans mysteries, celebrity culture, true crime, politics and technology, a snapshot of America’s increasingly eclectic listening habits.Apple’s 2025 data highlights several reasons behind the shift:The dethroning of legacy giants like The Daily shows how podcasting is moving away from strictly structured journalism toward looser, personality-driven formats.Apple’s rankings do more than list winners, they mark a turning point. A new leader now defines America’s listening habits, and the reasons behind that shift reflect broader cultural changes: longer attention spans for compelling conversations, a hunger for authenticity and the growing power of video-driven podcasting.For the first time in years, the old hierarchy has been disrupted. And if 2025 is any indication, America’s new No. 1 podcaster might represent where the entire medium is heading next.

“On October 24, 2025, Azure DDOS Protection automatically detected and mitigated a multi-vector DDoS attack measuring 15.72 Tbps and nearly 3.64 billion packets per second (pps). This was the largest DDoS attack ever observed in the cloud, and it targeted a single endpoint in Australia.

By utilising Azure’s globally distributed DDoS Protection infrastructure and continuous detection capabilities, mitigation measures were initiated. Malicious traffic was effectively filtered and redirected, maintaining uninterrupted service availability for customer workloads.

The attack originated from the Aisuru botnet. Aisuru is a Turbo Mirai-class IoT botnet that frequently causes record-breaking DDoS attacks by exploiting compromised home routers and cameras, mainly in residential ISPs in the United States and other countries.

These sudden UDP bursts had minimal source spoofing and used random source ports, which helped simplify traceback and facilitated provider enforcement.

Attackers are scaling with the internet itself. As fibre-to-the-home speeds rise and IoT devices get more powerful, the baseline for attack size keeps climbing.

As we approach the upcoming holiday season, it is essential to confirm that all internet-facing applications and workloads are adequately protected against DDOS attacks. Additionally, do not wait for an actual attack to assess your defensive capabilities or operational readiness—conduct regular simulations to identify and address potential issues proactively.”





Microsoft has announced that it prevented the largest-ever cloud DDoS (distributed denial-of-service) attack on its Azure cloud services, which occurred in October. In a report, the software giant noted that the Azure DDOS Protection tool automatically detected and mitigated a multi-vector attack that peaked at 15.72 Tbps (Terabits per second - the biggest ever in history) and nearly 3.64 billion packets per second (pps). The massive attack was successfully absorbed and filtered by Azure’s globally distributed DDoS Protection infrastructure, ensuring uninterrupted service availability for the customer.The attack was traced back to the Aisuru botnet, a Turbo Mirai-class IoT botnet known for exploiting compromised home routers and cameras to launch high-scale attacks. This incident underscores the rising threat landscape, where attack sizes scale with advances in the internet, such as increased fibre-to-the-home speeds and more powerful IoT devices.A DDoS (distributed denial-of-service) attack is a cyberattack where hackers use many infected devices to send massive amounts of fake traffic to a website or server. This flood of requests overwhelms the system, making it impossible for real users to access it. The target becomes so overloaded that it either crashes or slows down to the point where it stops working correctly.In a blog post, Sean Whalen, senior product marketing manager at Microsoft, wrote:

Article Title: Cloudflare outage explained: What is 'latent bug' that took the internet down, what company said
Article Text:
What Cloudflare said on the outage

Cloudflare down error message

What experts said on the outage







Cloudflare outage brought down hundreds of websites across the globe. Websites across the web crashed after what Cloudflare describes as a 'spike in unusual traffic.' The almost six-hour-long outage was caused by a latent bug. San Francisco-based Cloudflare provides the infrastructure and security for many websites worldwide. One of the company’s main areas of service is protecting websites against distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, which occur when multiple bad actors flood a website or network with traffic requests to overload it and degrade performance or cut off access.Some of the biggest websites that went down include ChatGPT, Twitter, Perplexity, Claude and also the outage-tracking site DownDetector. Other online services, including Grindr, Uber, Canva, Spotify, NJ Transit and League of Legends also experienced issues during the outage.The cause of the outage was a configuration file that is automatically generated to manage threat traffic, Jackie Dutton, a Cloudflare spokesperson said in a statement. There was no evidence of a cyberattack or malicious activity, the statement said. “The file grew beyond an expected size of entries and triggered a crash in the software system that handles traffic for a number of Cloudflare’s services,” said Dutton."In short, a latent bug in a service underpinning our bot mitigation capability started to crash after a routine configuration change we made. That cascaded into a broad degradation to our network and other services. This was not an attack,” Knecht wrote, referring to a bug that goes undetected in testing and has not caused a failure," Cloudflare's chief technology officer Dane Knecht wrote on Twitter.Some sites displayed the error message, “Please unblock challenges.cloudflare.com to proceed.”Explaining Cloudflare outage, information technology professor at the University of Notre Dame’s Mendoza College of Business, Mike Chapple, said that Cloudflare works behind the scenes to make the internet faster and safer, but when problems flare up “it results in massive digital gridlock” for internet users. Chapple further added that Cloudflare is a “content delivery network” that takes content from 20% of the world’s websites and mirrors them on thousands of servers worldwide.“When you access a website protected by Cloudflare, your computer doesn’t connect directly to that site,” Chapple said. “Instead, it connects to the nearest Cloudflare server, which might be very close to your home. That protects the website from a flood of traffic, and it provides you with a faster response. It’s a win-win for everyone, until it fails, and 20% of the internet goes down at the same time.”
Article Summary: Cloudflare outage brought down hundreds of websites across the globe. Websites across the web crashed after what Cloudflare describes as a'spike in unusual traffic' The almost six-hour-long outage was caused by a latent bug.

It provides several crucial functions that nearly all major modern websites use:Cloudflare caches (stores copies of) website data on its global network of servers.When you request a website, the data is served from the closest Cloudflare server, making the site load much faster.It acts as a shield, protecting websites from distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks, where hackers flood a site with junk traffic.It provides web application firewalls and security filters, stopping malicious requests before they reach the website’s original server.It handles the complex “phone book” of the internet, directing traffic to the correct IP addresses.The websites that experienced outages (like X, Spotify, etc.) did not experience problems with their own servers; they were experiencing a failure in the Cloudflare layer that sits in front of them. When a major internal error occurred in Cloudflare’s network, it caused a domino effect.Cloudflare has confirmed the disruption and said that it has immediately launched an investigation. According to the latest update issued the company said it is “working on restoring service for application services customers.”“We have made changes that have allowed Cloudflare Access and WARP to recover. Error levels for Access and WARP users have returned to pre-incident rates. We have re-enabled WARP access in London,” the company said in its previous update.“During our attempts to remediate, we have disabled WARP access in London. Users in London trying to access the Internet via WARP will see a failure to connect,” the company added.Users affected by the crash saw a message asking them to "please try again in a few minutes," pointing directly to an “internal server error on Cloudflare’s network.”The outage began around 12:00 UTC (5:30 pm IST) on November 18.
Article Summary: Hundreds of websites, including Twitter (X), Spotify, Canva, Claude and other big platforms went down after a massive technical failure. The scope of the incident was so big that even the outage tracking service Downdetector was temporarily affected by the same technical problems. Cloudflare has confirmed the disruption and said that it has immediately launched an investigation.

Article Title: Microsoft’s Windows 11 adds AI agents that run in the background to organise files and enhance productivity
Article Text:
Source: Windows Latest

What Agent workspace is and how it works in Windows 11

How AI agents interact with files and apps





Security and isolation features of Agent workspace





Parallel execution: Agents run alongside your main desktop without interruption.

Scoped authorisation: Each agent has a separate account and permission set.

Auditable actions: Users can monitor agent activities and adjust access as needed.

Also Read:





Microsoft is taking a major step toward making Windows 11 an AI-first operating system with its new experimental feature, Agent Workspace . This feature allows AI agents to run in the background with access to key personal folders, such as Documents, Desktop, Music, Pictures, and Videos, enabling them to perform tasks autonomously while users continue working on their normal desktop. Each agent operates in a separate, contained workspace with its own account, desktop, and permissions, ensuring a degree of isolation and control. While designed to enhance productivity by automating repetitive tasks, the feature also raises potential security and privacy concerns. Currently available only to Windows Insiders, Agent Workspace marks Microsoft’s push to integrate AI more deeply into everyday computing.Agent Workspace is a separate, contained Windows session dedicated to AI agents. Each agent gets its own desktop, account, permissions, and runtime, allowing it to work independently without disturbing the user’s main desktop. Users can turn on this optional feature through Settings > System > AI Components > Experimental Agentic Features.Once activated, agents can perform tasks such as opening applications, managing files, or running scripts, all in parallel with your regular workflow.Microsoft emphasises that this isolated workspace keeps agent actions auditable and controlled, ensuring you maintain visibility over what AI agents are doing.AI agents require access to local files and applications to perform tasks effectively. By using Windows’ Known Folders (Documents, Desktop, Downloads, Pictures, Music, Videos), agents can locate and manage files even if you’ve moved these folders elsewhere in your system.The workspace allows agents to read and write to these folders, enabling them to automate repetitive tasks like organising documents, creating presentations, or updating media libraries. Each agent’s permissions are scoped individually, so one agent’s access does not automatically extend to others.Microsoft designed Agent Workspace with security in mind. While it may seem similar to Windows Sandbox, there are key differences:Unlike Sandbox, which creates a fully isolated virtual environment and deletes activities on closure, AI agents can access personal folders while running. Microsoft is actively refining the security model to prioritise transparency, safety, and user control.With Agent Workspace, Windows 11 takes a significant step toward becoming an AI-native operating system. The goal is to provide AI assistance that works locally, automates repetitive tasks, and increases productivity while allowing users to stay in control. However, giving AI agents access to personal files introduces privacy and security concerns. The feature is still experimental and limited to Windows Insiders, and user feedback will likely shape its development before a wider release. Microsoft aims to balance innovation with safety, ensuring AI agents enhance workflows without compromising trust. As testing continues, developers are also evaluating how well these agents handle sensitive data, potential misuse risks, and the need for clear user permissions to maintain transparency and accountability.
Article Summary: Microsoft is taking a major step toward making Windows 11 an AI-first operating system with its new experimental feature, Agent Workspace. This feature allows AI agents to run in the background with access to key personal folders, such as Documents, Desktop, Music, Pictures, and Videos. While designed to enhance productivity by automating repetitive tasks, the feature also raises potential security and privacy concerns.

Article Title: Jeff Bezos to lead $6.2 billion AI startup Project Prometheus: Understanding the project and could this outpace ChatGPT
Article Text:
Source: Forbes

What is Jeff Bezos-led AI startup Project Prometheus

How Project Prometheus bridges research and real-world innovation

From LLMs to World Models: The next generation of AI innovation





Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s founder and one of the world’s richest people, is returning to an executive role as co-CEO of the AI startup Project Prometheus. This marks his first formal operational position since stepping down from Amazon in 2021 and signals his renewed focus on cutting-edge technology beyond his space venture, Blue Origin. Project Prometheus aims to develop advanced AI systems for robotics, drug discovery, and scientific innovation. Bezos’ return comes at a time of rapid global growth in AI, with increasing investment and a surge of startups transforming industries from software development to automation and scientific research. His involvement underscores the rising importance of AI in shaping the future of technology.Project Prometheus derives its name from Greek mythology, symbolising innovation and the transformative power of knowledge. The startup’s goal is to develop advanced AI systems capable of accelerating scientific discovery and performing complex physical tasks. These include robotics for automated operations, AI-driven drug discovery, and innovations across engineering, aerospace, and manufacturing.According to a Forbes report, the venture has already raised approximately $6.2 billion, making it one of the best-funded early-stage AI startups globally.A portion of this funding comes from Bezos himself, reflecting both his financial commitment and personal involvement in the company’s strategic direction. Project Prometheus has assembled an elite team of around 100 researchers and engineers. Many of these experts have been recruited from renowned AI labs such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind, and Meta. The team’s expertise spans robotics, machine learning, and applied AI research, positioning the startup to compete effectively in a highly competitive industry.As reported by The New York Times, Vik Bajaj, a former researcher at Google and co-leader of the project, has a notable background working on ambitious initiatives at Google X, such as Waymo, the self-driving car project, and Wing, a drone delivery service. His experience in developing breakthrough technologies complements Bezos’ strategic vision for Project Prometheus.Project Prometheus differentiates itself from conventional AI ventures that focus primarily on large language models (LLMs), such as those powering AI chatbots like ChatGPT. Instead, the startup is exploring “world models”; AI systems capable of understanding and interacting with the physical world, learning through observation and experimentation rather than relying solely on textual or digital data.Other startups pursuing similar approaches include Periodic Labs, which is designing AI-driven laboratories to conduct automated scientific experiments, and Physical Intelligence, which is backed by prominent investors such as Bezos, Khosla Ventures, Lux Capital, and OpenAI. These companies share the objective of bridging AI research and real-world applications, creating systems that can reason, plan, and innovate in tangible environments.Prominent AI experts, including Yann LeCun, Meta’s chief AI scientist, argue that LLMs have inherent limitations. While these models can process vast amounts of textual data and generate coherent outputs, they lack true understanding of the physical world. According to LeCun, they cannot perform reasoning tasks, anticipate outcomes, or plan actions in a way humans or even animals can.LeCun uses the example of visualising a cube rotating in space. Humans can effortlessly imagine its orientation and predict its movement. Current LLMs, however, cannot replicate this type of spatial reasoning or sensory understanding. This insight underlines the importance of the new generation of AI startups, including Project Prometheus, which aim to build systems capable of interacting with and learning from the real world.
Article Summary: Jeff Bezos is returning to an executive role as co-CEO of the AI startup Project Prometheus. This marks his first formal operational position since stepping down from Amazon in 2021. Project Prometheus aims to develop advanced AI systems for robotics, drug discovery, and scientific innovation. The venture has already raised approximately $6.2 billion.

It was the college roommate who found me crying, and acted on her urge to loan me a thousand dollars to keep me from having to drop out in my sophomore year,” she said.According to a report by Fortune, that roommate was Jeannie Ringo Tarkenton, who witnessed firsthand how her $1,000 gift transformed Scott's trajectory. Article Text:
Google’s expansion plan in Texas

Elon Musk responds to Google’s investment in Texas





Google CEO Sundar Pichai recently announced a sweeping investment of $40 billion in Texas through 2027. With this latest investment the company aims to expand its cloud and artificial intelligence infrastructure. Pichai described this initiative as strengthening the city Google calls “home,” includes new data centers in Armstrong and Haskell Counties and promises to reshape the state’s digital and energy landscape.“Today, we're announcing a new $40B investment in Texas through 2027 to build Cloud & AI infrastructure and support thousands of new jobs. This includes new data centers in Armstrong and Haskell Counties and a major investment to strengthen energy resilience and abundance. We're also providing funding to more than double the projected pipeline of new Texan electricians to power the AI era. We've proudly called Texas home for 15 years. Thank you@GregAbbott_TX for your continued support,” wrote Pichai in a post shared on X (formerly known as Twitter).With this latest investment in Texas Google aims to fund the construction of advanced facilities which will power Google’s AI and cloud services.Pichai also stressed on the fact that this expansion will also generate thousands of jobs and bolster energy resilience and abundance in the region.Along with this, Google has also pledged to finance workforce initiatives which are said to double Texas’ anticipated electrician pipeline and will make sure that the state can meet the growing demand for skilled labour in high-tech infrastructure.Tesla CEO Elon Musk has now reacted to the announcement made by Google CEO Sundar Pichai. Musk called the Google’s investment as mind-blowing. “It’s mind-blowing how much money is being spent on AI compute so fast!,” wrote Musk.However, he further added that “But still many orders of magnitude to go,” suggesting that investments made in the AI computing sector will continue to increase and will go far beyond the current levels.xAI, Elon Musk’s AI venture is also part of a a consortium with Nvidia, Microsoft, and BlackRock, which recently committed another $40 billion to build a separate Texas data center.The announcement made by Google comes at a time when concerns are rising over the energy footprint of AI data centers. The International Energy Agency’s World Energy Outlook 2025 report highlights that AI-driven infrastructure is fueling a surge in electricity demand, with natural gas re-emerging as a critical energy source as renewables struggle to keep pace.
